comments:
I run Eclipse with Java 1.4.2, but for my project I have to use 1.3.1.
Particularly immediately after starting Eclipse, the following error occurs:

The project was not built since its build path is incomplete. Cannot find the
class file for java.lang.Object.

Refreshing and cleaning the project sometimes helps when done several times
(project settings are OK and need not be changed). What helps is restarting
Eclipse and cleaning the output folder in the OS.

Only explanation would be that JRE container did not bind properly.
Moving to JDT/Debug which owns this container implementation.

Is there anything in your ".log"? Do you have steps that we can follow to 
reproduce the problem?

No, there is nothing suspicious in the .log (see attachment). What I do is: I
have a Java project open and quit Eclipse. When I start Eclipse, when it happens
(not always reproducible), then directly after start (no further action). When I
close the project and restart, it happens after opening the project.

Created an attachment (id=12240)
Eclipse log

The problem was also in RC1 and, I think, in M9, but not in M8.

I get the same problem in the M9 and later builds. My plugins use projects that 
have a Java nature, but do not use the package explorer. If I open my view and 
make a change that triggers code generation and a resulting Java build, I get 
the "The type java.lang.Object cannot be resolved" message. If I then open 
package explorer and click on "Java Build Path", the JRE is instantly added to 
the classpath and the problem goes away (no need to click on "OK"). My guess is 
that whatever triggers the loading of the JRE into the classpath is somehow 
dependent on package explorer initializing the Java model.

I'm not sure if this helps, but I noticed something strange on workspace 
startup. The EditorManager tries to restore the Java editor which indirectly 
calls becomeWorkingCopy() on the underlying compilation unit. The 
DeltaProcessingState.initalizeRoots() is called which tries to resolve the 
classpath, finally hitting JavaModelManager.variableGet("JRE_LIB"). Null is 
returned because of "Variable Initialization In Progress". Here is the stack 
trace:

Thread [main] (Suspended (breakpoint at line 1827 in JavaModelManager))
	JavaModelManager.variableGet(String) line: 1827
	JavaCore.getClasspathVariable(String) line: 1265

line: 78

(Object) line: 425

I can reproduce the problem.

The errors appear as red squiggly's in the editor, but do not appear in the 
problems view. The errors remain if I close/re-open the editor, but the 
problem does not occurr on evey workspace re-start (for example, when I debug 
with breakpoints the problem does not seem to occurr reliably).

The problem only occurrs when using JRE_LIB on the buildpath. I have not seen 
the problem occurr when using the JRE container. Here are the steps I used to 
reproduce:

* Launch a new empty workspace
* 'go to' the workbench (do not open the Java perspective)
* Create a new Java project (I imported JUnit) - do *not* change to Java 
perspective
* Set up build path to use JRE_LIB
* Open three editors - one for VectorTests, SimpleTest, and AllTests
* Close workspace
* Re-open workspace

-> Error appears on first character of each editor. Will attach screenshot

Created an attachment (id=12302)
screen shot

shows editor and error on first character

I'm not sure if this is Debug or JCORE - do you have any insight (Olivier or 
Philippe)?
Changing from the JRE_LIB variable to the JRE container fixed my prob. Thanks!

Re-assigning to JCORE. I've noticed that when this problem happens (and when 
it does not), the JRE_LIB initializer is only called once to initalize itself. 
The value appears to initialize properly, and only once. It could be that one 
editor foces the init, and the others fail since the first editor is causing 
the init doing the init.
Reproduced

It definitely looks like a concurrency issue in our land. I also saw the 
initialization occurring in 'main' thread.

Thread[main,6,main] CPVariable INIT - reentering access to variable during its 
initialization, will see previous value
Thread[main,6,main] 	variable: JRE_LIB

I know what is going on. Actually the successful scenario is the lucky one, 
where the failing one is the normal mode.

Problem lives in the JRE_LIB variable initializer. It get told to initialize, 
but tries to check against previous value to see if it has anything to do.
Actually, we trigger initializations for a good reason from JDTCore 
standpoint, even in multi-threaded mode, but this optimization in JDTLaunching 
is burning us, since we try to be resilient and answer sometimes a value 
inherited from previous sessions for reentering calls (need variable value 
while initializing it). In the past, we were answer null if reentering, and 
overtime we were able to retrieve the persisted value from previous session.
So you could still compare and take any action you want, except forgetting to 
set it in the end. Indeed, we will simply consider it not to be initialized at 
all, and will not perform correctly passed that point; since after first 
attempt for initializing, we flush our cache from previous sessions, since we 
cannot carry these over after initial attempt.

I checked that changing the method below addresses the problem 

on JavaClasspathVariablesInitializer:

private void setJREVariable(IPath newPath, String var) throws CoreException {
  JavaCore.setClasspathVariable(var, newPath, getMonitor());
}
Philippe, can I have your approval for RC3?
Fixed as suggested. Changes in JavaClasspathVariablesInitializer.
Please verify, Luc.
Verified.
see also Bug 88843

I've started getting this error message without any apparent reason today.  I've
never seen it before.  I'm running Eclipse 3.1.0.
